verses.verse: They came over to the other side of the sea into the country of the Gadarenes.
When he had come out of the ship, immediately, a man from the tombs with an unclean spirit met him,
who had his home in the tombs, and no one could tie him up, no, not even with chains.
For he had often been bound with foot shackles and chains, and the chains had been shattered to pieces by him, nor could anyone tame him.
Every day and night he was in the mountains and in the tombs screaming and cutting himself with stones.
But when he saw Jesus afar, he ran and kneeled down to him,
and screamed out with a loud voice and said, "What are you to do with me, Jesus, Son of the most high God? Swear in God's name that you won't torture me."
For he said to him, "Come out of the man, unclean spirit."
And he asked him, "What is your name?" He answered saying, "My name is Legion, for we are many."
And he earnestly pled with him that he wouldn't send them away out of the country.
Now there was near the mountains a large herd of pigs feeding,
and all the devils pled with him saying, "Send us into the pigs, so that we may enter them."

Right away Jesus gave them permission. The unclean spirits went out and entered the pigs. Then the herd ran violently down a steep place into the sea-there were about two thousand-and drowned in the sea.
Those who fed the pigs ran away and told [this] in the city and in the country; then they went out to see what it was that had happened.
They came to Jesus and saw the one who was possessed with the devils and had the "Legion", sitting, dressed, and in his right mind, and they were afraid.
And those who observed this told them how it happened to him who was possessed with the devils and what happened to the pigs.
And they started pleading with him to leave their area.
And when he got into the ship, he who had been possessed with the devils, plead with him, so that he might be with him.
But Jesus didn't allow him instead said to him, "Go home to your friends and tell them what great things the Lord has done for you and had compassion on you."
He left and started telling everyone in Decapolis what great things Jesus had done to him; and all marveled.
When Jesus had passed over again by ship to the other side, a lot of people gathered around him, and he was near the sea.
And look, one of the synagogue leaders came named Jairus. When he saw him, he fell at his feet,
earnestly pleading with him saying, "My little daughter is at the point of death. Come and lay your hands on her, so she may be healed, then she will live."
And he went with him. A of lot people followed him and crowded him.
Then a certain women who had a flow of blood twelve years,
and had suffered many things from many physicians, and had spent everything that she had, yet was not any better but instead grew worse.
When she heard about Jesus, went into the crowd behind [him] and touched his garment,
for she said, "If I can only touch his clothes, I will be well."
Immediately that fountain of her blood was dried up, and she felt in her body that she was healed of the plague.
But Jesus, immediately knowing in himself that miraculous power had gone from him turned around in that crowd and said, "Who touched my clothes?"
His disciples said to him, "You see the crowding squeezing around you, and you ask you touched me?"
But he looked around to see her who had done this.
And the woman fearing and trembling, knowing what had happened in her, came and prostrated before him and told him all the truth.
He said to her, "Daughter, your faith, has made you well; go in peace and be healed from your plague."
While he still spoke, there came one from the synagogue ruler's house who said, "Your daughter is dead; why trouble the Master any further?"
As soon as Jesus heard the message, which was spoken, he said to the ruler of the synagogue, "Do not be afraid, just believe."
He allowed no one to follow him except Peter, James, and John, the brother of James.
Then he came to the house of the ruler of the synagogue and saw the uproar and those who cried and loudly wailed.
When he had come in, he said to them, "Why all this uproar and sobbing? The girl is not dead just sleeping."
They derisively laughed at him, but after he had put them all out, he took the father and mother of the girl and those who were with him and went into the place where the girl was lying.
Then he took the girl by the hand and said to her, "Talitha cumi" which is-being interpreted- "Little girl, I say to you, get up."
Immediately the girl got up and walked, for she was twelve years old. They were bewildered with great astonishment.
And he strictly ordered them that no one should know about it and told them that something should be given to her to eat.
